properties.Name: Aamjiwnaang
properties.description:
Partner: Anishinabek Nation/Union of Ontario Indians
Partner Website: http://www.anishinabek.ca/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: N7T 7H5
Program Contact: Family Well-Being Coordinator
E-mail: laureen.linklater@anishinabek.ca
Phone Number: (705) 497-9127 x2237
Program Description: AN/UOI provides program coordination to Anishinabek First Nations. The vision for AN/UOI Nations includes: maintaining a safe place for people in the community, child and youth mental health services on every First Nation to ensure a timely response to mental health crises, communities that are better equipped to respond to and support children, youth and families in crisis, preventative approaches to support the break in the cycle of intergenerational trauma and violence, and resourcing best practices that support our Indigenous culture.

Partner Website: http://www.anishinabek.ca/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: P0T 3C0
Program Contact: Family Well-Being Coordinator
E-mail: laureen.linklater@anishinabek.ca
Phone Number: (705) 497-9127 x2237
Program Description: AN/UOI provides program coordination to Anishinabek First Nations. The vision for AN/UOI Nations includes: maintaining a safe place for people in the community, child and youth mental health services on every First Nation to ensure a timely response to mental health crises, communities that are better equipped to respond to and support children, youth and families in crisis, preventative approaches to support the break in the cycle of intergenerational trauma and violence, and resourcing best practices that support our Indigenous culture.

properties.Name: Batchewana First Nation
properties.description:
Partner: Association of Iroquois and Allied Indians
Partner Website: https://www.aiai.on.ca/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: P6A 5K9
Program Contact: Health and Wellness Policy Advisor
E-mail: zgeneral@aiai.on.ca
Phone Number: (519) 434-2761 x238
Program Description: AIAI's Family Well-Being program is focused on building on community strengths and external partnerships to design and deliver programs that support families and communities as a whole. Local program plans are in development around general themes of creating programs and services that include: traditional healing, culture and language, creating and improving local networks, increasing programming and services for children and youth, increasing child welfare supports, and capital and infrastructure.

properties.Name: Chippewas of Rama First Nation
properties.description:
Partner: Chippewas of Rama First Nation
Partner Website: http://www.mnjikaning.ca/Pages/default.aspx
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: L3V6H6
Program Contact: Manager of Social Services
E-mail: socialadmin@ramafirstnation.ca
Phone Number: (705) 235-3611
Program Description: The 'Ambe Minobmaadzidda' Program will promote and provide opportunities to engage in cultural teachings and ceremonies. The ‘Turtle Medicine Wheel’, designed specifically for this program, will be used as a cultural guide and teaching tool to learn to live in balance while building, maintaining and strengthening healthy relationships. The program focuses on Anishnaabek families, children and youth. Local activities include: traditional ceremonies, traditional teachings, traditional socials, spring fasting camp, Ojibway language immersion, family wellness plans, and a resource library.

properties.Name: Anishinaabeg of Kabapikotawangag Resource Council - Animakee Wa Zhing
properties.description:
Partner: Grand Council Treaty #3
Partner Website: http://www.akrc.on.ca/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: 49°23'19.7"N 95°07'39.8"W
Program Contact: Director of Operations
E-mail: director@akrc.on.ca
Phone Number: (807) 226-4445 x230
Program Description: Four regional lead agencies engaged and consulted with their communities to develop local program models that were based on 7 overarching themes: community resource coordination, family preservation, system navigation, prevention activities, cultural and traditional programming, family supports, and networking. The shared program objectives include: Family Well-Being workers to connect clients to existing services and programs in their community and to provide culturally based, preventative and holistic family supports; establishing community based programming for individuals and families; establishing a safe place to address crisis/emergency situations for children, youth and families; and establishing ongoing training and professional development for the Family Well-Being workers.

properties.Name: Bingwi Neyaashi Anishinaabek
properties.description:
Partner: Independent First Nations
Partner Website: http://www.bnafn.ca/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: P7B 2X6
Program Contact: Ending Violence Against Indigenous Women-Family Well-Being Program and Policy Advisor
E-mail: LisaT@ifnc.ca

Phone Number: (519) 706-0772
Program Description: The Ending Violence Against Indigenous Women Family Well-Being Program takes a holistic, family focused approach. IFN will coordinate and will support First Nation communities in program delivery. The client group for the Family Well-Being Worker is identified by each IFN Community, however this may include the whole family or specific family members and groups. Each local program will: provide supports, services and healing for the whole family and specific groups; provide land-based and culturally-based programming; offer workshops and education in the community about the causes of violence and how to live in a healthy way; offer case management for complex cases; and provide wrap-around services for families.

IFN will coordinate and will support First Nation communities in program delivery. The client group for the Family Well-Being Worker is identified by each IFN Community, however this may include the whole family or specific family members and groups. Each local program will: provide supports, services and healing for the whole family and specific groups; provide land-based and culturally-based programming; offer workshops and education in the community about the causes of violence and how to live in a healthy way; offer case management for complex cases; and provide wrap-around services for families.

properties.Name: Algoma
properties.description:
Partner: Métis Nation of Ontario
Partner Website: http://www.metisnation.org/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: P6A 1Y3
Program Contact: Manager of Operations, Healing and Wellness Branch
E-mail: ShelleyG@metisnation.org
Phone Number: (613) 798-1488 x125
Program Description: The program will have two distinct programming streams: cultural programs focused on outreach and cultural awareness training to the broad service sector to ensure cultural supports for Métis citizens and increased opportunities for youth leadership and direct services to Métis children, youth, families that are holistic and culturally reflective. The Métis FWBP will focus on Métis children, youth and their families, as well as outreach and education to mainstream service providers. Activities will cover a range that will target prevention through life skill development, involvement in culturally specific crafts, music, dancing, connecting with Elders and building healthy relationships. Client centered work will focus on advocacy, education and assisting with system navigation.

properties.Name: Mississaugas of the New Credit First Nation
properties.description:
Partner: Mississaugas of the New Credit First Nation
Partner Website: http://mncfn.ca/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: N0A 1H0
Program Contact: Manager of Operations, Healing and Wellness Branch
E-mail: ShelleyG@metisnation.org
Phone Number: (613) 798-1488 x125
Program Description: The 'Maamwi Gnawending' Program will provide prevention-focused services to families who are at risk of becoming involved with child and family services, women who have been exposed to or are at risk of being exposed to intimate partner violence, and children in care. Clients will be able to utilize cultural practices and have access to both Western and culturally-based materials and resources. Programs offered will be from both traditional and western perspectives, and will be facilitated by culturally sensitive staff members.

properties.Name: Mohawks of Akwesasne
properties.description:
Partner: Mohawk Council of Akwesasne
Partner Website: http://www.akwesasne.ca/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: 45.002780, -74.747625
Program Contact: Program Manager
E-mail: catherine.lelievre@akwesasne.ca
Phone Number: (613) 937-4322
Program Description: The focus of the program is to use a therapeutic educational model that is inclusive of cultural teachings and counseling modalities to create safe and therapeutic environments and wrap-around services for women, children and men to promote family well-being and growth. The program seeks to do this by addressing family violence by: providing safe housing options for women and children, men and families in separate housing units; offering educational and counseling opportunities in partnership to focus on prevention, safety planning and counseling; and having flexible service delivery with access to after-hours supports and mobile service delivery to reduce accessibility barriers due to lack of transportation and poverty.

The program seeks to do this by addressing family violence by: providing safe housing options for women and children, men and families in separate housing units; offering educational and counseling opportunities in partnership to focus on prevention, safety planning and counseling; and having flexible service delivery with access to after-hours supports and mobile service delivery to reduce accessibility barriers due to lack of transportation and poverty.

properties.Name: Albany
properties.description:
Partner: Nishnawbe Aski Nation
Partner Website: http://www.nan.on.ca/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: P0L 1H0
Program Contact: Family Well-Being Program Coordinator
E-mail: jkay@nan.on.ca
Phone Number: (807) 625-4939
Program Description: NAN coordinates the program for all NAN First Nations. The NAN FWBp will contribute to the vision of happy and healthy children and families in NAN communities where women and girls are safe, protected and respected. Further, the FWBp will support families to build healthy bonds, connections and relationships by empowering them and activating their voices through holistic and culturally appropriate healing processes. All NAN First Nations will deliver the Family Well-Being Program and will design and build the program according to the community’s needs and priorities, with guidance from NAN staff. Family Well-Being Workers will deliver the FWBp under the direction of community-level Health Directors and will work in collaboration with other community-based programs.

Program Description: NAN coordinates the program for all NAN First Nations. The NAN FWBp will contribute to the vision of happy and healthy children and families in NAN communities where women and girls are safe, protected and respected. Further, the FWBp will support families to build healthy bonds, connections and relationships by empowering them and activating their voices through holistic and culturally appropriate healing processes. All NAN First Nations will deliver the Family Well-Being Program and will design and build the program according to the community’s needs and priorities, with guidance from NAN staff. Family Well-Being Workers will deliver the FWBp under the direction of community-level Health Directors and will work in collaboration with other community-based programs.

The NAN FWBp will contribute to the vision of happy and healthy children and families in NAN communities where women and girls are safe, protected and respected. Further, the FWBp will support families to build healthy bonds, connections and relationships by empowering them and activating their voices through holistic and culturally appropriate healing processes. All NAN First Nations will deliver the Family Well-Being Program and will design and build the program according to the community’s needs and priorities, with guidance from NAN staff. Family Well-Being Workers will deliver the FWBp under the direction of community-level Health Directors and will work in collaboration with other community-based programs.

properties.Name: Fort Erie - Niagara Chapter Native Women
properties.description:
Partner: Ontario Native Women's Association
Partner Website: http://www.onwa.ca/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: L2A 1N9
Program Contact: Community Development Manager
E-mail: cmackay@onwa.ca
Phone Number: (807) 623-3442 x8588
Program Description: The 'Circles of Care' Program focuses on Indigenous women and their children who are involved with the child welfare system and violence against women sector, their families, and communities. The program is designed to support clients who arrive at the door “in crisis” by first stabilizing their current situation, and then building the support systems that are needed to move and stay away from crisis situations. Activities will include: working closely with clients to provide a circle of care that responds to the cultural, mental, physical, emotional and spiritual needs of the woman through close collaboration with Indigenous and non-Indigenous services in the community; providing direct services and advocacy support; and partnerships with other service providers across sectors to create culturally safe systems for Indigenous women and families to support their well-being.

Program Description: The 'Circles of Care' Program focuses on Indigenous women and their children who are involved with the child welfare system and violence against women sector, their families, and communities. The program is designed to support clients who arrive at the door “in crisis” by first stabilizing their current situation, and then building the support systems that are needed to move and stay away from crisis situations. Activities will include: working closely with clients to provide a circle of care that responds to the cultural, mental, physical, emotional and spiritual needs of the woman through close collaboration with Indigenous and non-Indigenous services in the community; providing direct services and advocacy support; and partnerships with other service providers across sectors to create culturally safe systems for Indigenous women and families to support their well-being.

properties.Name: 230 McArthur Avenue
properties.description:
Partner: Ottawa Inuit Children's Centre
Partner Website: http://www.ottawainuitchildrens.com/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: K1L 6P5
Program Contact: Manager of Family Well-Being
E-mail: jmessam@ottawainuitchildrens.com
Phone Number: (613) 744-3133 x211
Program Description: The Family Well-Being Program supports the well-being and capacity-building of the Inuit community. The program builds on the strengths of the child and their family and provides supports tailored to the unique needs of each family. The program’s emphasis is on prevention and cultural acquisition. The program focus is Inuit families, including women, men, adoptive parents, children and youth in the Ottawa area. The Family Well-Being Program model has five components: family intake coordination and parent outreach, cultural programming, safe spaces, individual support and crisis management, and capacity building.

properties.Name: Six Nations of the Grand River
properties.description:
Partner: Six Nations of the Grand River
Partner Website: http://www.sixnations.ca/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: N0A 1M0
Program Contact: Director of Social Services
E-mail: askye@sixnations.ca
Phone Number: (519) 445-2071
Program Description: The Six Nations Family Well-Being program will reflect a holistic Haudenosaunee way, culture and practices. It will also focus on prevention, family healing and wellness with the goal of reducing the incidence of children and youth entering the child welfare system, youth justice system and reducing family violence, build on existing community resources and programs to maximize existing resources and resources, develop a balance of mind, body, spirit and emotion, develop a “good mind” by demonstrating honesty, truth and integrity, and develop an understanding of how current behaviours impact the generations to come.

properties.Name: Ottawa
properties.description:
Partner: Tungasuvvingat Inuit
Partner Website: http://tungasuvvingatinuit.ca/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: K1L 7S1
Program Contact: Family Well-Being Manager
E-mail: fwb-mgr@tungasuvvingatinuit.ca
Phone Number: (613) 565-5885 x200
Program Description: Grounded in Inuit culture and traditions, TI's program seeks to facilitate opportunities for Inuit youth to be living Inummariq, facilitate early intervention, and reduce the harmful effects of violence on Inuit families by making community supports available for families in crisis. The program will focus on Inuit children, youth, women and their families in the Ottawa and Toronto regions.

properties.Name: Shawanaga First Nation
properties.description:
Partner: Independent First Nations
Partner Website: http://shawanagafirstnation.ca/
Postal Code or Geographic Coordinates: 45.513692, -80.273569
Program Contact: Ending Violence Against Indigenous Women-Family Well-Being Program and Policy Advisor
E-mail: LisaT@ifnc.ca
Phone Number: (519) 706-0772
Program Description: The Ending Violence Against Indigenous Women Family Well-Being Program takes a holistic, family focused approach. IFN will coordinate and will support First Nation communities in program delivery. The client group for the Family Well-Being Worker is identified by each IFN Community, however this may include the whole family or specific family members and groups. Each local program will: provide supports, services and healing for the whole family and specific groups; provide land-based and culturally-based programming; offer workshops and education in the community about the causes of violence and how to live in a healthy way; offer case management for complex cases; and provide wrap-around services for families.
